summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered consent judgments against a Pennsylvania man for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 17b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Philadelphia, alleges that, from at least April 2017 through at least June 2018, Father was placed in the care of his foster mother, who was an indicated perpetrator of child abuse. According to the complaint, the court found that Father violated Section 2511(a)(2) and (3) and ordered him to relinquish his parental rights to the children. The complaint further alleges that Father failed to comply with the court's orders and failed to show up for his court-ordered termination of parental rights.  In addition, the complaint alleges that he failed to attend a substance abuse assessment on September 26, 2017, before being arrested for a parole violation following the October 13, 2017 hearing, resulting in an unspecified period of incarceration.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Father consented to the entry of a consent judgment that permanently restrains his rights as a father, and orders him to pay a civil penalty of $10,000. The consent judgment also requires the court to determine whether the amount of disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil money penalties will be determined by the court at a later date. The court's order also prohibits Father from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any securities in connection with an offer to purchase or sell any security in the securities of a public company or a private company, and prohibits him from serving as an officer or director of an SEC-registered broker-dealer. The order also requires that the court consider whether the child is in a pre-adoptive home and whether it has a bond with its birth parent.  On the same day that the consent judgment was entered, the trial court issued a temporary restraining order against Father from violating the above-mentioned provisions of the federal securities laws, ordering him to return to the custody of his mother and father. The final judgment also prohibits the court from imposing any monetary penalty against the individual or entity responsible for the termination of the parental rights of a child under the age of 12 years of age. The Court also ordered the release of a copy of the final judgment, which is subject to court approval, on the basis of the facts of the case. In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Pennsylvania today announced criminal charges against Father. The criminal charges were filed against him.
